comment.author: 24231207@N07
comment._content: Russian Grand Duke. He visited NY in 1913. Killed in battle in 1915. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E05E0DF153BE233A...

comment.author: 26324687@N08
comment._content: No way! It was a rumor! He died in 1933. He fled Russia in 1920 before Bolsheviks entered Crimea. "He and his family, together with his mother-in-law, the Dowager Empress Maria Fyodorovna (Dagmar of Denmark), were rescued from the Crimea by British battleship HMS Marlborough in the quagmire of the 1917 Revolution, and thus they survived" - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Duke_Alexander_Mikhailovich_o...

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: "GRAND DUKE NOT DEAD.; Russian Headquarters Also Deny Turkish Official Reports of Victories" -- New York Times, January 13, 1915. The New York Times reported the above four days after they initially reported the article, dated January 9, 1915, linked by Cynthia Wenslow. This photograph appears to be dated April, 1913, and accordingly may have been "in the news" as a result of Michaelovitch's announced 1913 visit to New York.
